Please update your git-config.
Done
Is "host container ID" a concept that exists in DSP0248? I'm trying to understand whether this is implementing something we (IBM) invented or if it's part of the specification.
no, we do not have the "host Container ID" concept in the spec, we have added it as part of our use-case.

If this is not part of the standard, shouldn't we be very clear about documenting this as such and making sure that the "host container" derivation is well-defined, including what are the use-cases that lead to this?

> If this is not part of the standard, shouldn't we be very clear about documenting this as such

+1

I'd take a stronger stance. If this behaviour is outside of DSP0248 then IMO it doesn't have any business living in a part of the codebase that's implementing DSP0248. If the necessary behaviour impacts the specified behaviour then we should put in some effort to get it accepted into the specification.

As it stands the commit message tries to explain *what* and not nearly enough of the *why*. It really must properly explain the why. That said, I feel the whole design point needs actual documentation. Can we get something written down in a separate commit prior to this one?

Who is best placed to help us with this? Manoj?

A couple of points here :


1) I believe the wording in the commit message is slightly inaccurate in the context of a generic audience. I think `remote container id` [container id of an FRU from a remote PLDM end point].

2) And yes, I think `why` this API is needed & any references to the need for this API in the spec should be added to the commit message.

Although PDR normalization is a word that we[IBM] invented internally, DSP0248 talks about the concept of a Primary PDR repository & Merging the PDRs from a remote PLDM endpoint.

As per DSP0248 [https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0248_1.2.0.pdf] section 14:
One of the main functions of the PLDM discovery Agent[assuming a PLDM terminus like BMC] is maintaining a Primary PDR repository, adding/deleting/updating the PDRs to form a complete system model.

Here are the actual words from the Spec :

```
If the implementation is maintaining a Primary PDR Repository, the Discovery Agent may also be required to automatically create or update PDRs to support devices such as hot-plug devices that may be dynamically added or removed from the system. This includes the following actions:

 - creating records such as Terminus Locator PDRs
 - extracting Device PDR information and merging it into the Primary PDR Repository
 - updating associating records to link Device PDR information into the overall context of the platform management subsystem

Any OEM PDRs in the Device PDR information that are identified to be copied to the Primary PDR Repository are also added to the Primary PDR Repository by the Discovery Agent.

```

I believe the API being added here would help us update the container ID field of a PDR obtained from a remote PLDM terminus. And the discovery agent could leverage this API to merge the PDRs in such a way that it would complete the system model in the right contextual sense.


@pavithra - can you update the commit message to indicate all of this information a generic terms? And also the words like host e.t.c should be replaced with remote PLDM endpoint. I don't think there is any need to approach DMTF regarding the functionality as it is already covered in DSP0248

> I don't think there is any need to approach DMTF regarding the functionality as it is already covered in DSP0248

Excellent news.

> @pavithra - can you update the commit message to indicate all of this information a generic terms? And also the words like host e.t.c should be replaced with remote PLDM endpoint.

+100
I will update the commit message in the next patchset 😊
This breaks the API. If we merge this patch any callers will fail CI. Can we please come up with a new function name with an improved API and then deprecate this one?

Ack

New commit up - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/63585/1
Again this breaks the API. Please come up with a second function that can live in parallel so we can deprecate this one.
Ack

Please do not add functions whose only protection against UB is `assert()`.

You need to find a way to signal an error condition to the caller.
I missed this, will do it in next patchset.
Done
We're performing the same actions in both branches with different ordering. Can we instead introduce a temporary variable so that's not required?

We are doing different operations in both cases, first case we assign node->host_container_id = entity->entity_container_id and in the next case we assign node->host_container_id = node->entity.entity_container_id.

Are you referring to the common step that we are doing?
(node->entity.entity_container_id = next_container_id(tree))
Done
As above.
first "if" check has an extra condition and hence we are doing it.
Done
What does "file" mean in this context?  I don't think there is any file-io.
IBM has an OEM file IO implementation, but I don't know whether that's related. The use of "file" in this context strikes me as odd.
Resolved.
I think we can drop this paragraph as really it just repeats the patch subject line above.
Ack
Can you please be more specific about relevant sections here? DSP0248 is not huge, but also not small.
Done
Again, listing specific sections would be quite helpful here.
Done
Is there any particular significance to this? I think it's reasonable that we can expect something like this to be added by the patch without calling it out explicitly.
Ack

A couple of issues aside from several nitpicks:

1. The function name
2. The use of `assert()`
I have made all the changes in the next patchset.
nitpick: I think "from" might fit better here
Done

Added in what sense? Would "existing" be a better word to use?

Also is there any particular significance to the pointer being opaque? If not, do we need to mention that at all?
Ack

If the function is operating on a `struct pldm_entity_node` then I prefer we prefix the function name with `pldm_entity_node`: `pldm_entity_node_get_remote_container_id()`

Essentially, a strategy I find useful in C is to associate functions with data by prefixing the functions with the struct name. This is the C version of non-virtual methods (an approximation of a virtual method is a function pointer member in the struct).
Ack
Done

Please try to consistently wrap the commit message at 72 characters. My impression is that it's been done manually. Often your editor can help you wrap the lines to expectations (e.g. if you use `vim` you can use the sequence `gq` in visual mode)
Done

Can you please be specific about the name of the field you're adding, and if possible, its purpose. A vague subject like we currently have here makes it hard for me to remember the purpose of the change when sorting through the one line descriptions in Gerrit (and in the output of `git log`).

Oh, another established pattern is to prefix the subject with the affected subsystem. So in this case it should be something like:

`pdr: Introduce remote_container_id and associated APIs`
Ack

Please make sure the full stop goes after the end of the sentence (the sentence includes the reference in parentheses that currently follows the full stop). Also please make sure to have spaces where appropriate.
Done
Thanks for adding the section references!
Ack
Can we please try to stick to a single type of bracket. Currently we're mixing parentheses and square brackets throughout the commit message.
Done
Can elaborate on what API you're referring to here? The patch subject claims we're just adding a field to a structure.
Done

As it stands, it's not until this last sentence that I have some idea what actually happens in this patch.

This information needs to be in the patch subject and the opening sentences of the description.
Done
Hi Pavithra, thanks for the rework so far. I have some further comments.
Is this use of an errno value consistent with other functions in the `pldm_entity_*` APIs?
I am not sure about the other APIs as many of them make use of assert.
Done

It looks like there's a bit of a vertical alignment problem here. Can you please fix that?

Separately, I'd prefer we don't have quite so many spaces before the leading comment on the left and the diagram.
Done

Is this really a minimal unit test? Is it testing exactly one property is being upheld? It doesn't look like it from my brief inspection.

Please write unit tests such that they exercise a single property per test function and are a minimal test case for that property. Otherwise the implementations become an unwieldy mess and are next to impossible to maintain.

This is a test case where we have a minimal hierarchy of the system represented. It represents the parent node and children node concept. I have moved this test case to https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/63585 as we are making changes there.
Hi Pavithra, thanks for the rework. I have a couple of comments that must be addressed, but they are straight-forward.

We must not mark new functions as stable immediately. This must be changed to `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING`. I realise the other functions in this file are marked stable, and that I hadn't actually outlined when to use what annotation. I've set about documenting that now. See this patch:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/64074
Ack
Did I miss this one? If so, can you please add this annotation in a separate patch.
No, Andrew, it's already there - https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/src/pdr.c#L397, not sure why it came in my patchset.
Nitpick: can you please put the declarations at the top of the function so we're not mixing declarations and code?
Done
